A small portion of what I learned in this class will be helpful moving forward in a career of sustainability and natural resource management. Mostly though, you learn how to make the most profit from natural resources, not what is actually better for the environment. So be wary of that going into this class. Little of what Mendelsohn lectures and promotes is based on scientifically sound information. You also learn how to exploit climate change for profit; the professor explicitly states that his and the economically ideal amount of global warming is 4 degrees celsius; he's also said global warming will be highly beneficial mostly until 2050, and then we should start mitigating greenhouse gas emissions slowly. Though it's possible to account for human suffering in economics, this course definitely does not do that. For example, when Mendelsohn was lecturing that global warming will be beneficial to colder places because it will increase crop yields (incorrect) and improve tourism, I asked about the indigenous populations that live in the Artic who are suffering greatly because of rising temperatures, sea level rise and loss of ice. He answered that those populations are small and insignificant enough to leave out of calculations. I'm not truly surprised, but this course teaches economics that pretends that it's impossible to include climate justice and protecting vulnerable populations. Like most economics, it also grants corporations the same rights as individual human beings, so just be clear about that going into the course.

He was quite bad at explaining mathematical equations - I wish he had spent more time discussing the derivation of the formulas he presented.

The strength of this course is that it provides insight into the ways economics can be used to think about environmental challenges. For EVST majors or anyone going into the green economy or climate policy, it is helpful to learn about the ways in which economists view climate.

The main weakness of this course is that it feels strangely defeatist at times, with simplistic answers to complex issues that leave you wondering about the accuracy of the assumptions that are made. For example, Prof. Mendelsohn shows graphs mapping the cost of CO2 emissions mitigation (without explaining the assumptions that the models make about future technological improvement, damages linked to climate change, etc.)  and argues that we should not act in a way that is coherent with a 2C warming scenario because "it is too expensive - adaptation is much better. Let's aim for 4C." Really??

Strengths: The content of the course is extremely interesting
Weaknesses: I think the way the course is taught needs to be improved. These are the issues I had, which are also issues that many other students voiced as well: Many of the Psets were poorly worded and had a number of issues that made them difficult to solve properly (not because they were difficult but because of wording errors and logistics complications). There was only one office hours a week at a time when most students have class. The better time for office hours would be on the weekends or on Friday (after all the section classes have finished). The only time I could've gone to office hours was before my section had even met for that week, meaning I didn't fully know what I needed help on. Lastly, I think the delivery of the content in the course was at times very dry and while the content itself was incredibly interesting, it was delivered in a way that didn't make it engaging. More statistics, graphics, videos, contemporary content would really enhance the course.
